subject: Public Speaking
title: Evidence and the Burden of Proof
description: A quick, practical guide to Evidence and the Burden of Proof.

hook.text: Anyone can make a claim. The question is: can you back it up? That's the burden of proof in action.

buildup.text: In rhetoric, the person making the claim carries the burden. If you assert something, you owe the audience evidence.

discovery.text: Effective evidence comes in three forms: statistics, expert testimony, and concrete examples. Each serves a purpose.

twist.text: Too much evidence bores. Too little breeds skepticism. The art is choosing the right evidence, not all the evidence.

climax.text: A single vivid example often persuades more than a hundred statistics. Specificity beats volume.

punchline.text: One sharp fact cuts deeper than a pile of data.

quiz.question: What does the burden of proof require in rhetoric?
options: The audience must prove you wrong
The person making a claim must provide evidence
